elements.text: PART ONE
Hissing noise. Charley is struggling with effort.
Oh. Oh, Doctor.
Keep moving.
I'm trying
It's only Interzone resistance.
Oh, if I can only put one foot ahead of another. Oh, it's no good.
You mustn't stop, Charley.
Oh, Doctor, we have stopped. We're marking time like a pair of clockwork soldiers.
Keep trying. The force opposing us might give way.
Oh, we're up against a wall. An invisible wall.
Buzzing noise.
What's that? Insects? Oh, I can't see them but they're all around me. Oh, get off me. No, I can't stand it.
Charley.
Over my legs, my arms. Oh, my face!
Don't acknowledge them. They're from your imagination. Ignore them.
They're eating me alive! How can I ignore them? I'm their lunch. Oh, I can't stand this. I'm going back.
We must press on. Where one zone ends another must begin. We might find the Tardis in the next zone.
Get away! Oh, I can't stand it. Why don't they attack you?
I've already told you why.
Oh, they're real. Oh, they're in my hair, my eyes, my mouth. (gags) Oh, they're everywhere.
Charley, come here.
Don't touch me.
I have to, I'm sorry. Stand still, please.
No. Oh, Doctor, I don't need a hug.
Su shaka ha!
What? Oh! Oh! Su sh What was that?

That's an Okiya warrior cry. Useful for deflecting spirit attacks, dispersing hallucinations. Sort of audio insect spray. Trouble is, it only works once. I haven't had need of it since I was last with the Yaqui Indians.
I'm bitten, bruised, and for what? All we've gained is a couple of paces.
And yet the atmosphere seems different. Dryer. We could be crossing a fence. A defence.
Against what? There's nothing through there but, what, scrubby desert, blue rocks, evil orange sky.
A fierce red sun.
Two fierce red suns. Look, over there.
Crackling noise.
Doctor, what's happening?
Cover your ears. Close your eyes hard. Try to shield your thoughts.
I can't.
Charley, do as I say.
Charley? Charley. Hello there, Charley.
Who are you?
They call me the Kro'ka.
You're inside my head. Get out!
Charmed, I'm sure. You can't travel through the Interzone without my permission, so it might be better if you were a little (pause) nicer to me, Charley.
Who are you? What are you?
Someone trying to do his job.
You're scuttling through my thoughts. Scram!

Don't much like anger, and I certainly don't like spirit. Dear, oh dear, this isn't too promising. You're going to have to curb your rebellious tendencies if you wish to take your application further.
Doctor, are you okay? Can you hear what's going on?
Yes, yes, I'm here, here.
Well, help me. There's a voice.
I'm here. I'm here. Retract, reverse. Reset all coordinates.
The Kro'ka laughs, or rather wheezes.
The Doctor has problems of his own. He's trying to remember his, his mmm, I wonder what that is?
Doctor?
Oh, I like your mind, Charley. Such a worrier to response. How quaint. You care about your companion. How odd you individual entities are.
Just get lost, will you?
This is a lack of proper respect. I'm not just an Interzone guardian, I am a master of that art. I won't allow insults from would-be immigrants. Apologise.
No.
I can hurt you.
Try.
A challenge? Oh, thank you. Now then, what scares you? What makes you go 000 er I don't want to remember that. Ah, yes. There, I see. Let's go into that memory.
No!
Flames. I see flames burning. Some kind of flying craft, and you are inside. Ooo, very nice. This is a lovely memory, just right for purposes of punishment.
I don't want to remember.
But you must.
No, please.
The flames spreading, surrounding you.
Charley whimpers.

Burning from end to end. A wonderful sight from outside. Not so good if you're inside, is it? What's that smell? It's fat. It's body fat of others like you, frying in the furnace. And now, it's your turn.
No, please. Please.
Goodbye, Charley.
The R101 collapses in a fireball.
(echoing) Charley? Charley.
I'm here, next to you. Are we in the same place?
Yes. We've experienced mind games designed to turn us away from entering this new zone. What do they have to hide?
I'm not likely to find out, am I.
Why?
Because I'm pinned to the ground.
Oh yes, so am I. How annoying.
Why can't I move? I want to stand up. Why can't I?
We're held down by what must be a psychotronic force.
I was carried back to the R101 by this creepy voice.

Yes, he tried to slip into my thoughts. I managed to shut him out. He had to content himself with distorting my most potent synapses of memory. He led me to imagine the Tardis was in free fall towards a maelstrom of antimatter.
Sorry to interrupt, Doctor. Did you think you'd lost your big blue whatever that was? Oh, hello again, Charley. Feeling a little crispy? Good to know you're both all right now.
It was an entertaining trick. What else can you do, pull eggs out of peopleâ€™ ears?

Oh, I can do all sorts of tricks. Perhaps I'll show you some more later, yes? Now we must get on. Forms to fill in, procedures to follow. Question one. Do you still wish to enter the zone of Eutermes?
If you will be kind enough to allow it.

Ooo, very deferential. Charley, you should take lessons from him. Now, of course we can't just let anyone enter. You must have something to offer. Would you describe yourself as being an asset to society?
I most certainly would.
Your technical skills might be some use, but what about Charley here?
Well, we'd find her something to do.
Thanks, Doctor.
I think we'd best take another look into what passes as her mind, just to confirm her potential.
Don't you care, Doctor? Stop him.
Think one thought, and one thought only. Concentrate on an object. Anything. A plate of jam tarts.
I can't do it. I hate jam tarts.
Then order your synaptic dendritic tendrils to remain dormant.
What? My denudi what?
The Kro'ka laughs.
Very good. He's deliberately confused you. I can't make head nor tail of what you're thinking.
That's two of us.
Oh, let us get on. Question number two. What is the purpose of your visit?
Pleasure.
What's that?
Satisfaction.
Joy.
A feeling you might experience when you discover what you're searching for?
We're just a couple of sightseers. Ouch!

Lying makes the coils tighten, Doctor. Tell the truth if you wish to carry on breathing. That image you conjured up of an oblong box, is that what you hope to find in Zone Eutermes? Think, Doctor, or a tight spot might become even tighter.
Er, yes. I am on the lookout for my Tardis.
Tardis! Taaaardissssss. What is that? Your home? A hideaway? No, more a conveyance.
Yes, something like that.
Such things should not exist. I'm sorry, your application has been refused. Goodbye, Doctor.
Wait!
Well?
The Tardis is all of those things.
And more, perhaps?
Perhaps.
Does this Tardis possess technology suitable for space exploration?
It could do, but of course, we have to locate it first.
Yes. I have realised that's why you're here.
And we can't do that while pinned to the ground by you here.
We can hardly breathe.
I suppose you do need to breathe, Doctor.
I suppose I do.
All right, I will allow you to continue your search. There are people you will meet who will be interested in your, your Tardis and its technology. Perhaps you will help them. Release.
Oh!
Thank you.
Oh, Kro'ka?
Yes?
Can we just go?
Didn't I just say so? Yes, permission to enter Zone Eutermes is hereby granted.
Thank you.
Goodbye, Doctor, Charley. Report, Kro'ka two point seven oh. The experiment has begun.
Footsteps on crunchy ground.
So I wonder where we are?
Well, the landscape seems the same as we saw earlier.
Yeah, dry and dusty. Blech.
Parched. Look at the lines on those hills. Evidence of water courses.
Once, maybe, but not now. Perhaps Eutermes is suffering a drought?
The trees are dying. Their roots are cut off from what was once a river.
Why wouldn't the Kro'ka let us through? What's to hide?
There must be life somewhere. There must be technological development.
The Kro'ka seemed interested in the Tardis.
Yes. It was almost as it he was letting us in hoping we might somehow locate it.
Why?
We can worry about his interest when we find the old girl.
Yeah, I never thought I'd miss her so much. Look, Doctor.
Where?
Far distance, left.
No, there's dust. Ah, yes.
Lumps. Lumps sticking up, see?
Yes. That's where the Eutermeses must live. Biospheres.
They must be huge to stand out at this distance.
Listen.
Energy sound, then weapons fire in rapid bursts.
Down!
Is it firing at us?
No. Look, over there. A shadow running. See? I've lost him. I can't see.
What? Oh, there. He's human, sort of.
Where's he gone?
Can't see. He's the same colour as the rocks. There he is, running. Oh, no!
Boom!
Ah!
They killed him.
They're coming back for us. Run, Doctor!
No point.
Why don't they fire at us too?
They're observing us, maybe recording our images. Seeking advice from the Kro'ka, perhaps?
Energy sound fades away.
We must have clearance. Charley, where
Doctor, this creature just moved.
Creature? He looks a lot like you.
Thanks a lot.

Oh, come on, Charley. Open your mind. Of course, I don't recognise the species, but trapped here I wouldn't expect to. Basic humanoid form. You know, two arms, two legs. Charley, say hello to the first person we've met in our new home.
Doctor, is that bone running across its, his head, on the outside?

Vestigial exoskeleton, perhaps. Notice it comes from the back of the neck straight over and round the eyes, nose, and mouth. Probably ancient protection that evolved away over the years. You are familiar with Darwin, aren't you?
No, Doctor. I didn't 'ave no education, me, guv.
I met Charles once. Managed to put him off reptiles for life. Well, almost. Anyway, he'd have been fascinated by this fellow.
Doctor, he moved!
Reflex, perhaps. No, you're right. He's trembling, shaking.
He's alive!
His skin is wrinkled, cracking. Dehydration. He needs water, to be immersed in water. We'll carry him to the river. I saw some pools there. Take his legs. Hurry!
All right, Doctor. Give me a chance. Oh!
Splashing in running water. The alien begins to revive.
Am I dead and gone to Samor, then?
Samor?
Heaven, perhaps, or Elysium?
Oh, his eyes, they're open. Look at them. Yellow, like a jungle cat.
Have you noticed his skin tones? They've lightened in the water.
Almost blue, like a chameleon. More natural defence mechanisms, perhaps. His people were possibly preyed upon once rather than being the hunters. And the people in that craft were shooting at him.
Yes, Charley, you may well be right. Good to see the odd bit of my intellect has rubbed off on you during our travels.
The alien wakes with a start.
Ah! Who are you? Monsters. Monsters everywhere. Haven't you hurt me enough?
I am the Doctor. This is Charlotte.
Charley, to my friends.
Drink. Drink. Please, let me drink.
Here. Oh, no cup, just my hands.
(gulps) Again. More. More. Let me go into the waters. I need to drink deep.
All right.
Splashing.
Stop him. Stop him. He's trying to drown.
Hey, keep still. What are you doing? We're trying to help you, stupid.
We won't harm you. Stop, please. Please, stop this.
What have you done with L'Da?
L'Da? What? Who is L'Da?
I can't bear being without her. Oh, give me the elixir if that's what I must do to be with her.
Doctor?
Wait. This elixir of which you speak, what will it do?
Make me a king. King C'Rizz.
pronounced Ker-iz
You don't really want that.
Don't I?
You were running away. Not exactly a kingly attribute.
Charley!
I wanted to find my home, my piece of land, my village, but it's all dust. Oh, L'Da, L'Da.
pronounced Lyda.
Who is L'Da?
The woman I was to join with for life.
Did you escape from one of the biospheres?
Alpha Sphere. I got free. They hunted me down. I stumbled, fell, knocked myself out. They must have thought I was dead. Are they coming back? I can hear them.
It's just the wind blowing dead tree branches.
Who was it sent that gunship after you?
Who do you think?
We've only just arrived.
Why would anyone come here, of all the places on Eutermes?
We have something we have to find.
I pity you. You have come to an evil place.
Why?
There is a blight, brought by the Kromon. They put a curse upon the land.
The Kromon?
I have no more strength. I have nothing more to give or to say. But you're right, Charlotte. To run away was not worthy. I must return, free L'Da.
C'Rizz, wait.
You must rest. We all must. Tomorrow we will decide what direction is best to take.
I will not speak. I will not say what I have seen. I ask only that you don't harm L'Da.
Hey, C'Rizz, stop. Stop. Doctor, help me. He's trying to get up.
C'Rizz, you've suffered a bad dream, that's all.
Wasn't a dream. Memory. Oh.
Was it about the Kromon?
We're not your enemy, C'Rizz. Please, believe that.
You spoke of someone you love. L'Da?
Is she in danger?
Danger? No, she's being well cared for.
Who by?
Who do you think?
The Kromon.
Yes.
You hate them because they've taken L'Da from you.

No, I don't know what happened. I was inducted, taken with L'Da to Alpha Sphere. There were hundreds of us. We were graded, assessed for work and usefulness, divided into groups. Everyone was herded away until only L'Da and I were left. We were told we were chosen as the Elect. Designated as potential royals.
What does that mean?
I never found out.
Are the Kromon native to this zone?
Zone?
To, to here. This country, this world.
No, they're not like us. Like giant isoptera.
Ilsoptera? Oh, ants.
Termites, to be more precise. Go on.
They have big heads with antennae, horns, mouths that can tear you, sacs of poison in their throats to sting or kill.
They sound delightful. Can't wait to meet them.
Don't joke, Charlotte.
Please, it's just Charley.
C'Rizz, did the Kromon construct the biospheres?
Yes, I think so.
They dictate what goes on inside?
They control everything. Everyone.
But not you.
No.
How did you escape?

We were given a liquid to drink. Clear, bitter tasting, strange. They called it the Elixir. Poor L'Da drank, then I did too, but I couldn't keep it down. My body rebelled, but I'd absorbed enough to act the way they wanted me to be. We were taken into a chamber where they said the scrolls were kept. This knowledge, the secret history of the Kromon, was to be imparted to us. We were to be prepared so as to become part of the Kromon when required.
How?
What was their history?

I didn't receive enough information. The little Elixir I'd ingested was leaving me. But I saw and felt enough. I glimpsed the soul of the Kromon. It was like a vision from the pit of deepest Hell. I screamed, ran, got clear eventually. I reached the lower sections and hid myself inside a soil transporter and was carried free of Alpha Sphere. Then they came after me.
That's when we saw them swoop down on you?
You saved my life.
The Kromon have advanced technology, machines, gunships. The engineers know how to build biospheres.
Yes, I suppose.
Unless it's instinct. Can you remember when the Kromon first appeared?
My father said, when I was still a child. Before the land became dry.
Are all the biospheres the same?
I don't know. But at the induction, they were dividing us into castes. Some into management, some to food production, some to research workshops.
Research? Into what?
I don't know.
What is it, Doctor?

I'm wondering if they might have our Tardis. That Kro'ka made hints, as if he had some foreknowledge. He also suggested that someone, possibly these Kromon, might be more than a little interested in the possibilities of space flight. They could be holding the Tardis in their workshops.
It won't do them much good, will it?
No, but it would greatly benefit us, Charley.
What are you saying? I don't understand.
Just a little speculation.
I shouldn't have run away, abandoned L'Da. I must go back to try and save her.
They almost killed you once, C'Rizz.
I might as well be dead without her.
You should rest. You're shivering again.
Use the rocks as a wind break.
Help me find her, please.
We'll see how things are in the morning.
What can we do, stuck out in this dust bowl?
We can rest.
Yes. I'm tired.
long rattling exhales behind the dialogue.
Didn't take him long.
Are you all right?
Cold.
Think warm thoughts.
These stones are hard.
They're filled with the softest down.
Yes, all right. Swan's down, is it?
Of course. Nothing but the best.
That's all right, then. Goodnight, Doctor.
Goodnight, Charlotte.
Oi! Oh, can you turn the wind down a bit?
Footsteps.
Oh, I need a drink. Can we stop? I've got half the dust of this valley stuck down my throat.
Here.
Oh, thanks.
Pulls stopper out of container and drinks.
Oh, that's better.
When did the rains cease?
They haven't.
Are you sure?
It still rains, just as it always did.
Really? Yet the land's so dry. The river's down to almost a trickle.
We must move on. I'd like to reach a biosphere by nightfall.
Howling wind.
Doctor? Doctor! I can't see you.
[OC]: Here! Over here.
C'Rizz?
Behind you. Hold on to me.
Where? I can't see. (coughs) Oh, nothing but blown dust. Pah. Oh, er oh!
Charlotte, let me help you. Take my hand. Come on.
Oh, dust everywhere. Eyes, throat.
Keep hold of me. We mustn't lose each other. These dust storms can bury you, choke you to death.
Can you see the Doctor?
No, I can't see anything much at all.
Doctor! Doctor! (coughs) Can you hear him?
I'm not sure. The wind's blowing right at us. Let me turn. Shield me, Charlotte. No, nothing. Maybe he's sheltering somewhere.
Where? There's nothing but open ground.
We're heading for some fallen trees. Keep straight anead. Maybe the Doctor'll be waiting for us there.
Which way is straight ahead?
Er, that. No, follow me. What is it, Charlotte?
You're beginning to sound just like the Doctor.
Is that bad?
Let's move. Oh, hold on to me hard.
The wind has stopped.
(coughs) C'Rizz? Where are you, C'Rizz?
What?
Oh, you frightened me. Look at you, a dust devil. Your skin's changed again. You look rusty.
Can you not alter your skin tones? Your flesh seems weak, unprotected. Are you all right?
Thirsty.
Did you keep hold of that water gourd?
Oh, yes. Oh, buried somewhere. Ah, yes! (blows off dust) Here.
There's a mouthful each.
Oh, thanks. Look at this place. The landscape's changed. Great mounds of red dust, and no sign of the Doctor. What's happened to him? He will be safe, won't he?
We should be able to see him, unless he's fallen and been buried. Doctor? Doctor!
Nothing.
Wait. There is something.
The Doctor, is he calling? Can you hear him?
No. Down.
The sound of a gunship approaching.
We lie flat. They mustn't see us. I'll shield you.
The gunship flies over and away.
I don't think they saw us.
What on Earth's happened to the Doctor? We can see quite a way now. Where can he have got to?
Wait. Look.
What?
Straight ahead. By that mound. See a line under the dust moving? See?
What is it?
It's the path of an Oroog.
An 0? A what?
They live underground. They're diggers, fur covered, big claws. I thought they'd all be captured.
It's moving towards us. Oh, not anymore. Where's it going?
The Oroog is leading us away. he's stopped. Let's see what he has to show us.
Footsteps.
Is this a good idea?
What else can we do?
What if it's waiting to eat us?
An Oroog? Don't be silly. Ah, this is where he's stopped.
What are we supposed to see? There's nothing except a half-buried tree.
Hello, you two.
Doctor!
Would you care to lift a few branches from my lower limbs so we can resume our journey?
Are you all right?
I believe so.
What happened to you?

After you went off at a tangent, I sheltered by what I thought was a stout piece of the local flora. There was then a collapse of said stout flora that trapped me under its branches. How did you find me?
An Oroog guided us. He's still around. They occasionally surface and say hello.
Hello. Have you any more lost friends?
No, but thank you for guiding help my way.
Yes, thanks. Sorry we can't shake hands.
(laughing) Yes, mine are a little large, and my claws are just a little mucky.
You need a manicure.
I like you, you're funny. What is your name?
Charlotte. Charley to my friends.
May I call you Charley?
You may. This is the Doctor, C'Rizz.
Indeed, I am honoured to meet you
Thank you.

C'Rizz. I didn't know many of your particular kind still thrived. Charley, I am an Oroog. My clan name is probably unpronounceable in your language. All my brothers and sisters have been taken. I may well be the last Oroog outside captivity.
You know there's a patrol ship in the area?
Yes. Getting closer. I can feel vibrations through the ground. I don't think they're too friendly.
The gunship is near.
They've seen something.
Me, Doctor.
Keep down.
They must have seen us now.
Go, get away while you can.
They can see my move, locate you. I'd better stay.
The gunship leaves.
It's gone.
A harsh, crackly voice. Close cousin of the Kaleds, sounds like.
You will all remain standing. You will wait for the return of the patrol ship. You will be taken to Alpha Sphere for interrogation and induction.
And if we refuse?
You have zero choice in the matter.
I have. Bye, bye, everyone.
Stun the Oroog.
Energy weapons. The Oroog groans.
No!
He has not been terminated. He is a valuable asset.
And what about us? Do we have any value?
This is not my task. In the Alpha Sphere, you will be assessed as to your value to the Kromon. If useful, you will be put to work.
And if we aren't?
You will be turned into fertilizer.
Quite a choice. Ah, the transport's arrived.
Tighten the net further.
2: Yes, Commander.
Ow!
That is too much. We don't require dead prisoners. That's better. Return to your duty.
Commander, any chance of a glass of water, please?
Liquid is precious. We will not waste it on you.
3: Contact made with Alpha Sphere, Commander.
Inform them we are bringing in an Oroog. We will require a restraining cage until he is pacified.
They're talking about you.
We do have a temper when we're confined against our will.
Why put up with this, then?
(chuckles) Oh, this isn't the place or the moment.
We're being treated like animals.
That's what we are to them.
I am an animal.
No offence.
None taken.
C'Rizz
Don't use my name.
Why haven't they questioned you? It's only yesterday you were their prime target.
I don't know.
Maybe the Kromon only think in lines of straight logic. If you, as C'Rizz, were reported dead, you can't possibly be alive. Therefore, you must be someone else.
I'd use a different name from now on.
Like what?
Choose. Any.
I know. Z'Ricc. (pronounced Zerik) It's sort of C'Rizz, only mixed up a bit.
Z'Ricc. Thanks.
It's hot, isn't it. This contact with my fur making you too warm?
I'm trying not to think about it.
It's even hotter inside my fur.
Can we please talk about something else, gentlemen.
Such as?
I've been wondering why the Kromon accept Charley and I.
We couldn't be further away from Commander Termite in looks.
Yet they accept us without question.
To them you're just another alien species, like the Oroog, like me. You're a commodity that they use for whatever suits their purpose.
By using the Elixir?
It changed L'Da so much.
Interesting to experience their modus operandi.
I do hope there won't be unpleasantness.
So do I, but I must recover my Tardis. This ship's probably driven by compressed hydrogen combustion. Ramjet effect. Quite sophisticated. They might be able to decipher the secrets of time travel.
What travel?
Time. Mmm, never mind. Ah, we're descending into one of the biospheres.
This is Alpha Sphere, Doctor, where I escaped from. It's the home of the Kromon. It's where we'll all die.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
CHARLEY: Oh. Oh, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Keep moving.
CHARLEY: I'm trying
DOCTOR: It's only Interzone resistance.
CHARLEY: Oh, if I can only put one foot ahead of another. Oh, it's no good.
DOCTOR: You mustn't stop, Charley.
CHARLEY: Oh, Doctor, we have stopped. We're marking time like a pair of clockwork soldiers.
DOCTOR: Keep trying. The force opposing us might give way.
CHARLEY: Oh, we're up against a wall. An invisible wall.
CHARLEY: What's that? Insects? Oh, I can't see them but they're all around me. Oh, get off me. No, I can't stand it.
DOCTOR: Charley.
CHARLEY: Over my legs, my arms. Oh, my face!
DOCTOR: Don't acknowledge them. They're from your imagination. Ignore them.
CHARLEY: They're eating me alive! How can I ignore them? I'm their lunch. Oh, I can't stand this. I'm going back.
DOCTOR: We must press on. Where one zone ends another must begin. We might find the Tardis in the next zone.
CHARLEY: Get away! Oh, I can't stand it. Why don't they attack you?
DOCTOR: I've already told you why.
CHARLEY: Oh, they're real. Oh, they're in my hair, my eyes, my mouth. (gags) Oh, they're everywhere.
DOCTOR: Charley, come here.
CHARLEY: Don't touch me.
DOCTOR: I have to, I'm sorry. Stand still, please.
CHARLEY: No. Oh, Doctor, I don't need a hug.
DOCTOR: Su shaka ha!
CHARLEY: What? Oh! Oh! Su sh What was that?
DOCTOR: That's an Okiya warrior cry. Useful for deflecting spirit attacks, dispersing hallucinations. Sort of audio insect spray. Trouble is, it only works once. I haven't had need of it since I was last with the Yaqui Indians.
CHARLEY: I'm bitten, bruised, and for what? All we've gained is a couple of paces.
DOCTOR: And yet the atmosphere seems different. Dryer. We could be crossing a fence. A defence.
CHARLEY: Against what? There's nothing through there but, what, scrubby desert, blue rocks, evil orange sky.
DOCTOR: A fierce red sun.
CHARLEY: Two fierce red suns. Look, over there.
CHARLEY: Doctor, what's happening?
DOCTOR: Cover your ears. Close your eyes hard. Try to shield your thoughts.
CHARLEY: I can't.
DOCTOR: Charley, do as I say.
KRO'KA: Charley? Charley. Hello there, Charley.
CHARLEY: Who are you?
KRO'KA: They call me the Kro'ka.
CHARLEY: You're inside my head. Get out!
KRO'KA: Charmed, I'm sure. You can't travel through the Interzone without my permission, so it might be better if you were a little (pause) nicer to me, Charley.
CHARLEY: Who are you? What are you?
KRO'KA: Someone trying to do his job.
CHARLEY: You're scuttling through my thoughts. Scram!
KRO'KA: Don't much like anger, and I certainly don't like spirit. Dear, oh dear, this isn't too promising. You're going to have to curb your rebellious tendencies if you wish to take your application further.
CHARLEY: Doctor, are you okay? Can you hear what's going on?
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, I'm here, here.
CHARLEY: Well, help me. There's a voice.
DOCTOR: I'm here. I'm here. Retract, reverse. Reset all coordinates.
KRO'KA: The Doctor has problems of his own. He's trying to remember his, his mmm, I wonder what that is?
CHARLEY: Doctor?
KRO'KA: Oh, I like your mind, Charley. Such a worrier to response. How quaint. You care about your companion. How odd you individual entities are.
CHARLEY: Just get lost, will you?
KRO'KA: This is a lack of proper respect. I'm not just an Interzone guardian, I am a master of that art. I won't allow insults from would-be immigrants. Apologise.
CHARLEY: No.
KRO'KA: I can hurt you.
CHARLEY: Try.
KRO'KA: A challenge? Oh, thank you. Now then, what scares you? What makes you go 000 er I don't want to remember that. Ah, yes. There, I see. Let's go into that memory.
CHARLEY: No!
KRO'KA: Flames. I see flames burning. Some kind of flying craft, and you are inside. Ooo, very nice. This is a lovely memory, just right for purposes of punishment.
CHARLEY: I don't want to remember.
KRO'KA: But you must.
CHARLEY: No, please.
KRO'KA: The flames spreading, surrounding you.
KRO'KA: Burning from end to end. A wonderful sight from outside. Not so good if you're inside, is it? What's that smell? It's fat. It's body fat of others like you, frying in the furnace. And now, it's your turn.
CHARLEY: No, please. Please.
KRO'KA: Goodbye, Charley.
DOCTOR: (echoing) Charley? Charley.
CHARLEY: I'm here, next to you. Are we in the same place?
DOCTOR: Yes. We've experienced mind games designed to turn us away from entering this new zone. What do they have to hide?
CHARLEY: I'm not likely to find out, am I.
DOCTOR: Why?
CHARLEY: Because I'm pinned to the ground.
DOCTOR: Oh yes, so am I. How annoying.
CHARLEY: Why can't I move? I want to stand up. Why can't I?
DOCTOR: We're held down by what must be a psychotronic force.
CHARLEY: I was carried back to the R101 by this creepy voice.
DOCTOR: Yes, he tried to slip into my thoughts. I managed to shut him out. He had to content himself with distorting my most potent synapses of memory. He led me to imagine the Tardis was in free fall towards a maelstrom of antimatter.
KRO'KA: Sorry to interrupt, Doctor. Did you think you'd lost your big blue whatever that was? Oh, hello again, Charley. Feeling a little crispy? Good to know you're both all right now.
DOCTOR: It was an entertaining trick. What else can you do, pull eggs out of peopleâ€™ ears?
KRO'KA: Oh, I can do all sorts of tricks. Perhaps I'll show you some more later, yes? Now we must get on. Forms to fill in, procedures to follow. Question one. Do you still wish to enter the zone of Eutermes?
DOCTOR: If you will be kind enough to allow it.
KRO'KA: Ooo, very deferential. Charley, you should take lessons from him. Now, of course we can't just let anyone enter. You must have something to offer. Would you describe yourself as being an asset to society?
DOCTOR: I most certainly would.
KRO'KA: Your technical skills might be some use, but what about Charley here?
DOCTOR: Well, we'd find her something to do.
CHARLEY: Thanks, Doctor.
KRO'KA: I think we'd best take another look into what passes as her mind, just to confirm her potential.
CHARLEY: Don't you care, Doctor? Stop him.
DOCTOR: Think one thought, and one thought only. Concentrate on an object. Anything. A plate of jam tarts.
CHARLEY: I can't do it. I hate jam tarts.
DOCTOR: Then order your synaptic dendritic tendrils to remain dormant.
CHARLEY: What? My denudi what?
KRO'KA: Very good. He's deliberately confused you. I can't make head nor tail of what you're thinking.
CHARLEY: That's two of us.
KRO'KA: Oh, let us get on. Question number two. What is the purpose of your visit?
DOCTOR: Pleasure.
KRO'KA: What's that?
DOCTOR: Satisfaction.
CHARLEY: Joy.
KRO'KA: A feeling you might experience when you discover what you're searching for?
DOCTOR: We're just a couple of sightseers. Ouch!
KRO'KA: Lying makes the coils tighten, Doctor. Tell the truth if you wish to carry on breathing. That image you conjured up of an oblong box, is that what you hope to find in Zone Eutermes? Think, Doctor, or a tight spot might become even tighter.
DOCTOR: Er, yes. I am on the lookout for my Tardis.
KRO'KA: Tardis! Taaaardissssss. What is that? Your home? A hideaway? No, more a conveyance.
DOCTOR: Yes, something like that.
KRO'KA: Such things should not exist. I'm sorry, your application has been refused. Goodbye, Doctor.
CHARLEY: Wait!
KRO'KA: Well?
CHARLEY: The Tardis is all of those things.
KRO'KA: And more, perhaps?
CHARLEY: Perhaps.
KRO'KA: Does this Tardis possess technology suitable for space exploration?
DOCTOR: It could do, but of course, we have to locate it first.
KRO'KA: Yes. I have realised that's why you're here.
DOCTOR: And we can't do that while pinned to the ground by you here.
CHARLEY: We can hardly breathe.
KRO'KA: I suppose you do need to breathe, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I suppose I do.
KRO'KA: All right, I will allow you to continue your search. There are people you will meet who will be interested in your, your Tardis and its technology. Perhaps you will help them. Release.
CHARLEY: Oh!
DOCTOR: Thank you.
CHARLEY: Oh, Kro'ka?
KRO'KA: Yes?
CHARLEY: Can we just go?
KRO'KA: Didn't I just say so? Yes, permission to enter Zone Eutermes is hereby granted.
DOCTOR: Thank you.
KRO'KA: Goodbye, Doctor, Charley. Report, Kro'ka two point seven oh. The experiment has begun.
CHARLEY: So I wonder where we are?
DOCTOR: Well, the landscape seems the same as we saw earlier.
CHARLEY: Yeah, dry and dusty. Blech.
DOCTOR: Parched. Look at the lines on those hills. Evidence of water courses.
CHARLEY: Once, maybe, but not now. Perhaps Eutermes is suffering a drought?
DOCTOR: The trees are dying. Their roots are cut off from what was once a river.
CHARLEY: Why wouldn't the Kro'ka let us through? What's to hide?
DOCTOR: There must be life somewhere. There must be technological development.
CHARLEY: The Kro'ka seemed interested in the Tardis.
DOCTOR: Yes. It was almost as it he was letting us in hoping we might somehow locate it.
CHARLEY: Why?
DOCTOR: We can worry about his interest when we find the old girl.
CHARLEY: Yeah, I never thought I'd miss her so much. Look, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Where?
CHARLEY: Far distance, left.
DOCTOR: No, there's dust. Ah, yes.
CHARLEY: Lumps. Lumps sticking up, see?
DOCTOR: Yes. That's where the Eutermeses must live. Biospheres.
CHARLEY: They must be huge to stand out at this distance.
DOCTOR: Listen.
DOCTOR: Down!
CHARLEY: Is it firing at us?
DOCTOR: No. Look, over there. A shadow running. See? I've lost him. I can't see.
CHARLEY: What? Oh, there. He's human, sort of.
DOCTOR: Where's he gone?
CHARLEY: Can't see. He's the same colour as the rocks. There he is, running. Oh, no!
CHARLEY: Ah!
DOCTOR: They killed him.
CHARLEY: They're coming back for us. Run, Doctor!
DOCTOR: No point.
CHARLEY: Why don't they fire at us too?
DOCTOR: They're observing us, maybe recording our images. Seeking advice from the Kro'ka, perhaps?
DOCTOR: We must have clearance. Charley, where
CHARLEY: Doctor, this creature just moved.
DOCTOR: Creature? He looks a lot like you.
CHARLEY: Thanks a lot.
DOCTOR: Oh, come on, Charley. Open your mind. Of course, I don't recognise the species, but trapped here I wouldn't expect to. Basic humanoid form. You know, two arms, two legs. Charley, say hello to the first person we've met in our new home.
CHARLEY: Doctor, is that bone running across its, his head, on the outside?
DOCTOR: Vestigial exoskeleton, perhaps. Notice it comes from the back of the neck straight over and round the eyes, nose, and mouth. Probably ancient protection that evolved away over the years. You are familiar with Darwin, aren't you?
CHARLEY: No, Doctor. I didn't 'ave no education, me, guv.
DOCTOR: I met Charles once. Managed to put him off reptiles for life. Well, almost. Anyway, he'd have been fascinated by this fellow.
CHARLEY: Doctor, he moved!
DOCTOR: Reflex, perhaps. No, you're right. He's trembling, shaking.
CHARLEY: He's alive!
DOCTOR: His skin is wrinkled, cracking. Dehydration. He needs water, to be immersed in water. We'll carry him to the river. I saw some pools there. Take his legs. Hurry!
CHARLEY: All right, Doctor. Give me a chance. Oh!
C'RIZZ: Am I dead and gone to Samor, then?
CHARLEY: Samor?
DOCTOR: Heaven, perhaps, or Elysium?
CHARLEY: Oh, his eyes, they're open. Look at them. Yellow, like a jungle cat.
DOCTOR: Have you noticed his skin tones? They've lightened in the water.
CHARLEY: Almost blue, like a chameleon. More natural defence mechanisms, perhaps. His people were possibly preyed upon once rather than being the hunters. And the people in that craft were shooting at him.
DOCTOR: Yes, Charley, you may well be right. Good to see the odd bit of my intellect has rubbed off on you during our travels.
C'RIZZ: Ah! Who are you? Monsters. Monsters everywhere. Haven't you hurt me enough?
DOCTOR: I am the Doctor. This is Charlotte.
CHARLEY: Charley, to my friends.
C'RIZZ: Drink. Drink. Please, let me drink.
CHARLEY: Here. Oh, no cup, just my hands.
C'RIZZ: (gulps) Again. More. More. Let me go into the waters. I need to drink deep.
CHARLEY: All right.
DOCTOR: Stop him. Stop him. He's trying to drown.
CHARLEY: Hey, keep still. What are you doing? We're trying to help you, stupid.
DOCTOR: We won't harm you. Stop, please. Please, stop this.
C'RIZZ: What have you done with L'Da?
CHARLEY: L'Da? What? Who is L'Da?
C'RIZZ: I can't bear being without her. Oh, give me the elixir if that's what I must do to be with her.
CHARLEY: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Wait. This elixir of which you speak, what will it do?
C'RIZZ: Make me a king. King C'Rizz.
CHARLEY: You don't really want that.
C'RIZZ: Don't I?
CHARLEY: You were running away. Not exactly a kingly attribute.
DOCTOR: Charley!
C'RIZZ: I wanted to find my home, my piece of land, my village, but it's all dust. Oh, L'Da, L'Da.
DOCTOR: Who is L'Da?
C'RIZZ: The woman I was to join with for life.
DOCTOR: Did you escape from one of the biospheres?
C'RIZZ: Alpha Sphere. I got free. They hunted me down. I stumbled, fell, knocked myself out. They must have thought I was dead. Are they coming back? I can hear them.
CHARLEY: It's just the wind blowing dead tree branches.
DOCTOR: Who was it sent that gunship after you?
C'RIZZ: Who do you think?
DOCTOR: We've only just arrived.
C'RIZZ: Why would anyone come here, of all the places on Eutermes?
DOCTOR: We have something we have to find.
C'RIZZ: I pity you. You have come to an evil place.
CHARLEY: Why?
C'RIZZ: There is a blight, brought by the Kromon. They put a curse upon the land.
DOCTOR: The Kromon?
C'RIZZ: I have no more strength. I have nothing more to give or to say. But you're right, Charlotte. To run away was not worthy. I must return, free L'Da.
CHARLEY: C'Rizz, wait.
DOCTOR: You must rest. We all must. Tomorrow we will decide what direction is best to take.
C'RIZZ: I will not speak. I will not say what I have seen. I ask only that you don't harm L'Da.
CHARLEY: Hey, C'Rizz, stop. Stop. Doctor, help me. He's trying to get up.
DOCTOR: C'Rizz, you've suffered a bad dream, that's all.
C'RIZZ: Wasn't a dream. Memory. Oh.
CHARLEY: Was it about the Kromon?
DOCTOR: We're not your enemy, C'Rizz. Please, believe that.
CHARLEY: You spoke of someone you love. L'Da?
DOCTOR: Is she in danger?
C'RIZZ: Danger? No, she's being well cared for.
CHARLEY: Who by?
C'RIZZ: Who do you think?
DOCTOR: The Kromon.
C'RIZZ: Yes.
DOCTOR: You hate them because they've taken L'Da from you.
C'RIZZ: No, I don't know what happened. I was inducted, taken with L'Da to Alpha Sphere. There were hundreds of us. We were graded, assessed for work and usefulness, divided into groups. Everyone was herded away until only L'Da and I were left. We were told we were chosen as the Elect. Designated as potential royals.
DOCTOR: What does that mean?
C'RIZZ: I never found out.
DOCTOR: Are the Kromon native to this zone?
C'RIZZ: Zone?
DOCTOR: To, to here. This country, this world.
C'RIZZ: No, they're not like us. Like giant isoptera.
CHARLEY: Ilsoptera? Oh, ants.
DOCTOR: Termites, to be more precise. Go on.
C'RIZZ: They have big heads with antennae, horns, mouths that can tear you, sacs of poison in their throats to sting or kill.
CHARLEY: They sound delightful. Can't wait to meet them.
C'RIZZ: Don't joke, Charlotte.
CHARLEY: Please, it's just Charley.
DOCTOR: C'Rizz, did the Kromon construct the biospheres?
C'RIZZ: Yes, I think so.
DOCTOR: They dictate what goes on inside?
C'RIZZ: They control everything. Everyone.
CHARLEY: But not you.
C'RIZZ: No.
DOCTOR: How did you escape?
C'RIZZ: We were given a liquid to drink. Clear, bitter tasting, strange. They called it the Elixir. Poor L'Da drank, then I did too, but I couldn't keep it down. My body rebelled, but I'd absorbed enough to act the way they wanted me to be. We were taken into a chamber where they said the scrolls were kept. This knowledge, the secret history of the Kromon, was to be imparted to us. We were to be prepared so as to become part of the Kromon when required.
CHARLEY: How?
DOCTOR: What was their history?
C'RIZZ: I didn't receive enough information. The little Elixir I'd ingested was leaving me. But I saw and felt enough. I glimpsed the soul of the Kromon. It was like a vision from the pit of deepest Hell. I screamed, ran, got clear eventually. I reached the lower sections and hid myself inside a soil transporter and was carried free of Alpha Sphere. Then they came after me.
CHARLEY: That's when we saw them swoop down on you?
C'RIZZ: You saved my life.
DOCTOR: The Kromon have advanced technology, machines, gunships. The engineers know how to build biospheres.
C'RIZZ: Yes, I suppose.
DOCTOR: Unless it's instinct. Can you remember when the Kromon first appeared?
C'RIZZ: My father said, when I was still a child. Before the land became dry.
DOCTOR: Are all the biospheres the same?
C'RIZZ: I don't know. But at the induction, they were dividing us into castes. Some into management, some to food production, some to research workshops.
DOCTOR: Research? Into what?
C'RIZZ: I don't know.
CHARLEY: What is it, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I'm wondering if they might have our Tardis. That Kro'ka made hints, as if he had some foreknowledge. He also suggested that someone, possibly these Kromon, might be more than a little interested in the possibilities of space flight. They could be holding the Tardis in their workshops.
CHARLEY: It won't do them much good, will it?
DOCTOR: No, but it would greatly benefit us, Charley.
C'RIZZ: What are you saying? I don't understand.
DOCTOR: Just a little speculation.
C'RIZZ: I shouldn't have run away, abandoned L'Da. I must go back to try and save her.
CHARLEY: They almost killed you once, C'Rizz.
C'RIZZ: I might as well be dead without her.
DOCTOR: You should rest. You're shivering again.
CHARLEY: Use the rocks as a wind break.
C'RIZZ: Help me find her, please.
DOCTOR: We'll see how things are in the morning.
CHARLEY: What can we do, stuck out in this dust bowl?
DOCTOR: We can rest.
C'RIZZ: Yes. I'm tired.
CHARLEY: Didn't take him long.
DOCTOR: Are you all right?
CHARLEY: Cold.
DOCTOR: Think warm thoughts.
CHARLEY: These stones are hard.
DOCTOR: They're filled with the softest down.
CHARLEY: Yes, all right. Swan's down, is it?
DOCTOR: Of course. Nothing but the best.
CHARLEY: That's all right, then. Goodnight, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Goodnight, Charlotte.
CHARLEY: Oi! Oh, can you turn the wind down a bit?
CHARLEY: Oh, I need a drink. Can we stop? I've got half the dust of this valley stuck down my throat.
C'RIZZ: Here.
CHARLEY: Oh, thanks.
CHARLEY: Oh, that's better.
DOCTOR: When did the rains cease?
C'RIZZ: They haven't.
DOCTOR: Are you sure?
C'RIZZ: It still rains, just as it always did.
CHARLEY: Really? Yet the land's so dry. The river's down to almost a trickle.
DOCTOR: We must move on. I'd like to reach a biosphere by nightfall.
CHARLEY: Doctor? Doctor! I can't see you.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Here! Over here.
CHARLEY: C'Rizz?
C'RIZZ: Behind you. Hold on to me.
CHARLEY: Where? I can't see. (coughs) Oh, nothing but blown dust. Pah. Oh, er oh!
C'RIZZ: Charlotte, let me help you. Take my hand. Come on.
CHARLEY: Oh, dust everywhere. Eyes, throat.
C'RIZZ: Keep hold of me. We mustn't lose each other. These dust storms can bury you, choke you to death.
CHARLEY: Can you see the Doctor?
C'RIZZ: No, I can't see anything much at all.
CHARLEY: Doctor! Doctor! (coughs) Can you hear him?
C'RIZZ: I'm not sure. The wind's blowing right at us. Let me turn. Shield me, Charlotte. No, nothing. Maybe he's sheltering somewhere.
CHARLEY: Where? There's nothing but open ground.
C'RIZZ: We're heading for some fallen trees. Keep straight anead. Maybe the Doctor'll be waiting for us there.
CHARLEY: Which way is straight ahead?
C'RIZZ: Er, that. No, follow me. What is it, Charlotte?
CHARLEY: You're beginning to sound just like the Doctor.
C'RIZZ: Is that bad?
CHARLEY: Let's move. Oh, hold on to me hard.
CHARLEY: (coughs) C'Rizz? Where are you, C'Rizz?
C'RIZZ: What?
CHARLEY: Oh, you frightened me. Look at you, a dust devil. Your skin's changed again. You look rusty.
C'RIZZ: Can you not alter your skin tones? Your flesh seems weak, unprotected. Are you all right?
CHARLEY: Thirsty.
C'RIZZ: Did you keep hold of that water gourd?
CHARLEY: Oh, yes. Oh, buried somewhere. Ah, yes! (blows off dust) Here.
C'RIZZ: There's a mouthful each.
CHARLEY: Oh, thanks. Look at this place. The landscape's changed. Great mounds of red dust, and no sign of the Doctor. What's happened to him? He will be safe, won't he?
C'RIZZ: We should be able to see him, unless he's fallen and been buried. Doctor? Doctor!
CHARLEY: Nothing.
C'RIZZ: Wait. There is something.
CHARLEY: The Doctor, is he calling? Can you hear him?
C'RIZZ: No. Down.
C'RIZZ: We lie flat. They mustn't see us. I'll shield you.
C'RIZZ: I don't think they saw us.
CHARLEY: What on Earth's happened to the Doctor? We can see quite a way now. Where can he have got to?
C'RIZZ: Wait. Look.
CHARLEY: What?
C'RIZZ: Straight ahead. By that mound. See a line under the dust moving? See?
CHARLEY: What is it?
C'RIZZ: It's the path of an Oroog.
CHARLEY: An 0? A what?
C'RIZZ: They live underground. They're diggers, fur covered, big claws. I thought they'd all be captured.
CHARLEY: It's moving towards us. Oh, not anymore. Where's it going?
C'RIZZ: The Oroog is leading us away. he's stopped. Let's see what he has to show us.
CHARLEY: Is this a good idea?
C'RIZZ: What else can we do?
CHARLEY: What if it's waiting to eat us?
C'RIZZ: An Oroog? Don't be silly. Ah, this is where he's stopped.
CHARLEY: What are we supposed to see? There's nothing except a half-buried tree.
DOCTOR: Hello, you two.
CHARLEY: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Would you care to lift a few branches from my lower limbs so we can resume our journey?
CHARLEY: Are you all right?
DOCTOR: I believe so.
CHARLEY: What happened to you?
DOCTOR: After you went off at a tangent, I sheltered by what I thought was a stout piece of the local flora. There was then a collapse of said stout flora that trapped me under its branches. How did you find me?
C'RIZZ: An Oroog guided us. He's still around. They occasionally surface and say hello.
OROOG: Hello. Have you any more lost friends?
DOCTOR: No, but thank you for guiding help my way.
CHARLEY: Yes, thanks. Sorry we can't shake hands.
OROOG: (laughing) Yes, mine are a little large, and my claws are just a little mucky.
CHARLEY: You need a manicure.
OROOG: I like you, you're funny. What is your name?
CHARLEY: Charlotte. Charley to my friends.
OROOG: May I call you Charley?
CHARLEY: You may. This is the Doctor, C'Rizz.
OROOG: Indeed, I am honoured to meet you
DOCTOR: Thank you.
OROOG: C'Rizz. I didn't know many of your particular kind still thrived. Charley, I am an Oroog. My clan name is probably unpronounceable in your language. All my brothers and sisters have been taken. I may well be the last Oroog outside captivity.
C'RIZZ: You know there's a patrol ship in the area?
OROOG: Yes. Getting closer. I can feel vibrations through the ground. I don't think they're too friendly.
C'RIZZ: They've seen something.
OROOG: Me, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Keep down.
CHARLEY: They must have seen us now.
C'RIZZ: Go, get away while you can.
OROOG: They can see my move, locate you. I'd better stay.
C'RIZZ: It's gone.
KROMON: You will all remain standing. You will wait for the return of the patrol ship. You will be taken to Alpha Sphere for interrogation and induction.
DOCTOR: And if we refuse?
KROMON: You have zero choice in the matter.
OROOG: I have. Bye, bye, everyone.
KROMON: Stun the Oroog.
CHARLEY: No!
KROMON: He has not been terminated. He is a valuable asset.
DOCTOR: And what about us? Do we have any value?
KROMON: This is not my task. In the Alpha Sphere, you will be assessed as to your value to the Kromon. If useful, you will be put to work.
CHARLEY: And if we aren't?
KROMON: You will be turned into fertilizer.
DOCTOR: Quite a choice. Ah, the transport's arrived.
KROMON: Tighten the net further.
KROMON: 2: Yes, Commander.
CHARLEY: Ow!
KROMON: That is too much. We don't require dead prisoners. That's better. Return to your duty.
CHARLEY: Commander, any chance of a glass of water, please?
KROMON: Liquid is precious. We will not waste it on you.
KROMON: 3: Contact made with Alpha Sphere, Commander.
KROMON: Inform them we are bringing in an Oroog. We will require a restraining cage until he is pacified.
CHARLEY: They're talking about you.
OROOG: We do have a temper when we're confined against our will.
C'RIZZ: Why put up with this, then?
OROOG: (chuckles) Oh, this isn't the place or the moment.
CHARLEY: We're being treated like animals.
C'RIZZ: That's what we are to them.
OROOG: I am an animal.
C'RIZZ: No offence.
OROOG: None taken.
CHARLEY: C'Rizz
C'RIZZ: Don't use my name.
DOCTOR: Why haven't they questioned you? It's only yesterday you were their prime target.
C'RIZZ: I don't know.
DOCTOR: Maybe the Kromon only think in lines of straight logic. If you, as C'Rizz, were reported dead, you can't possibly be alive. Therefore, you must be someone else.
CHARLEY: I'd use a different name from now on.
C'RIZZ: Like what?
DOCTOR: Choose. Any.
CHARLEY: I know. Z'Ricc. (pronounced Zerik) It's sort of C'Rizz, only mixed up a bit.
C'RIZZ: Z'Ricc. Thanks.
OROOG: It's hot, isn't it. This contact with my fur making you too warm?
C'RIZZ: I'm trying not to think about it.
OROOG: It's even hotter inside my fur.
DOCTOR: Can we please talk about something else, gentlemen.
C'RIZZ: Such as?
DOCTOR: I've been wondering why the Kromon accept Charley and I.
CHARLEY: We couldn't be further away from Commander Termite in looks.
DOCTOR: Yet they accept us without question.
C'RIZZ: To them you're just another alien species, like the Oroog, like me. You're a commodity that they use for whatever suits their purpose.
DOCTOR: By using the Elixir?
C'RIZZ: It changed L'Da so much.
DOCTOR: Interesting to experience their modus operandi.
OROOG: I do hope there won't be unpleasantness.
DOCTOR: So do I, but I must recover my Tardis. This ship's probably driven by compressed hydrogen combustion. Ramjet effect. Quite sophisticated. They might be able to decipher the secrets of time travel.
C'RIZZ: What travel?
DOCTOR: Time. Mmm, never mind. Ah, we're descending into one of the biospheres.
C'RIZZ: This is Alpha Sphere, Doctor, where I escaped from. It's the home of the Kromon. It's where we'll all die.

elements.text: PART TWO
(with a northern accent) Bring them forward. Stand by to subdue the Oroog. Set beams to stun only.
2: (Gumby-ish) It is done. Squad, ready.
Release them. Leave the Oroog. Aliens, move away.
That's you, Doctor.
Good luck, Oroog.
Yes.
Cage the Oroog. Remove him from the excavation site. Have him pacified, trained, put to work with the other diggers. Bring the aliens to me.
2: Where are you from?
Gallifrey.
That is not a coherent answer. Are you from a neighbouring zone?
We came from one, yes.
You were allowed in?
Yes.
2: You must have some use. What is it?
I've often wondered.
You informed immigration you have certain skills that could be useful to us, correct?
I can't remember. Your immigration service is somewhat eccentric.
I can assign you to labouring duties. What is it that you do?
Well
2: Hesitation means doubt. Can you garden?
Er, no.
Aqua-engineer?
No.
2: What use are you? Answer quickly, or you will be categorised as fit only for fertilizer.
I've often thought I have a talent for space flight.
That requires further interview with research personnel at the highest level.
I thought it might.
2: Lying will lead to instant annihilation.
Quite right too.
After pacification, arrange for his interview with SoaceOp Research.
2: I will.
You, female. Name?
Charlotte.
Age?
None of your business.
She's far older than she appears.
But still within breeding age.
Breeding?
Unusual humanoid. Let genetics assess her potential. Place her on the reproductive reserve.
2: Pacification also?
Temporary. Move her aside.
What? Hey!
You, a native. Why are you covered in filth?
Your gunship didn't let us use its washing facilities.
You seem rebellious. Note, he is to be ultra-pacified. What uses have you?
I can farm, look after land, cattle.
Yes, yes, so do most of your kind. Name?
Er, Z'Ricc.
How barbaric. Put him in the central garden labour force. Interview complete. Take them to L lab.
Excuse me. Can I apply for an alternative position?
No. Repro is for you.
I need her as my assistant.
You can't have her.
What if I make a formal request?
What if I send you for composting. Processing is complete. Take them to L lab. Pacify them.
Walking
At least we're in the same place where I last saw L'Da.
Is the whole place linked by galleries like this?
Yes. There's a central transport system, open containers on rails, used mostly for moving materials between levels.
This L lab we're being taken to.
That's where we're turned into willing workers.
Pacification?
The liquid they tried to give me. It takes you into the mind of the Kromon. You accept everything they tell you, and believe in their cause absolutely.
That's something to look forward to. Oh, it's hot, humid. Why is everything so damp? Fountains spouting water everywhere you look.
The Kromons seem to constantly need to take in liquid.
Some insect-like species can only survive in these watery conditions.
And the smell. It's like living inside a compost heap.
4: Stop speaking. You will wait here.
When we are in L Lab, you must let me go first. Be ready.
3: Be quiet.
Can't we run for it here, get lost in the gloom?
They've three laserforce weapons.
3: Silence.
Yes, sir. I'd better get used to saying that.
Weapons fire.
Ow! Hey, that hurt my arm!
3: It is the lightest touch beam. The next will be harder.
4: L lab will relieve us of the aliens now.

The process is simple. You will be given a phial of liquid. You will hold the Elixir in your mouth until I order you to swallow. You will then experience a certain sleepiness. You will begin to hear voices, see sights you have never witnessed before. Your thoughts will be changed and guided into acceptable modes of behaviour. Let us begin.
Let me get it over with first.
3: You will take your turn as ordered.
That doesn't matter. Let him go first. Seat yourself. Lie back.
It's like watching someone at the dentist.
Makes you want to run right out the door.
Yes, it does.
3: Do not talk unless you wish more pain.
No, thanks.
Ready?
Yes.
Open. Slowly. Slowly. Put the liquid on your tongue. That's good. Slowly let it go to the back of your throat. Let it slide.
C'Rizz starts to choke.
What's the matter?
I can't. I can't. I'm going to be sick.
Keep your lips closed tight.
I can't.
Projectile vomit.
Run! Go, Charley, Doctor, now!
Weapons fire.
Charley, go right.
Yes, Doctor.
Run!
Weapons stop.
Right, this way.
What about C'Rizz?
We'll try to rescue him later. Just for the minute, try to stay alive.
Running on metal, weapons in background.
But it's only a matter of time before we meet more Kromon soldiers ahead of us.
There must be a side passage somewhere. Try to keep up, Charley.
I'm trying. What do you think I'm doing?
There is no reason why the Elixir cannot be ingested. This was a deliberate attempt to allow the two aliens to escape.
I can't hold down that Elixir stuff.
You realise that I have authority to dispose of recaltricent subjects? Have you recaptured the aliens?
3: Not yet, but they will soon be arrested. I have ordered more soldiers to this sector. What is to be done regarding this native?
I have decided the Elixir rejection was a deliberate tactic to allow escape.
No, I told you
3: Silence!
He's therefore deemed unsuitable for pacification. Take him to the fertilization plant. Dispose of him.
3: It shall be done. Move! Unless you wish to be destroyed here.
I'd sooner die than take that mind poison again.
Then you shall shortly achieve your wish. Take him away.
3: Move!
Walking.
There must be a linking passage somewhere.
I think I can hear. Yes, someone's coming. Let's turn back.
No, we must take a chance. What's that ahead, to the left?
It's too murky to see. I think it's just a shadow.
It might be a side exit. Yes, it is. It's a side opening. Hurry. Wait, wait, wait. Stand very still. Charley, be very quiet.
Footsteps approach and recede.
Doctor, did you see who was with them?
Was it C'Rizz?
I'm sure it was.
Let's see where they're taking him.
3: Keep moving.
What's the hurry? Is there a shortage of fertilizer?
3: It will be a pleasure to see you face the cutting beams of execution, to hear you scream, smell the burn of your flesh.
At least I'll die knowing the Kromon failed to control one of our minds.

3: Only because your body is weak and puny. Many of your kind cannot digest the Elixir. We do not require their contribution, other than to feed the fungi. Hold his arms. Stay close. I do not wish any agitation before we reach the site of execution.
Walking on crunchy stuff.
We've lost them.
What is this place? What are those great things?
Fungi of some sort. It's a processing plant. They mentioned fertilizer. As quietly as we Can.
I can see C'Rizz. Doctor, they're getting ready to kill him.
Keep close. We're almost within range.
Range of what? We haven't got any weapons.
Yes, we have. Here, round the base of the fungus, there's mud. Muck. We can throw that, cause a diversion. If we can dodge down the lines of fungi, we might get clear.
Or not.
Oh, you are in a positive mood today. Now, time to get our hands dirty. Take two
handfuls, Charley.
Urgh. What is it?
Never mind. Roll the mud into a ball. When I shout Howzat! hurl it at them. Aim for the Kromon leader.
Like a coconut shy.
Ready to aim?
3: Execution squad, ready.
Howzat! Throw, Charley, now!
Splats and noises from the Kromon.
Oh, yes! Direct hit, Doctor. Well done.
C'Rizz, run! Charley, this way. Zig zag.
Weapons fire.
C'Rizz, over here. This way.
Stop!
3: Find the aliens. Don't let this one escape. Find them!
Thanks. I thought that I was dead.
Least we could do.
Doctor, aren't we heading back to that L lab place?
Yes. Stop. Whoa. Look, they put a guard outside.
Just one. He hasn't seen us.
Yet.
We'll have to get past him.
Charley, wait.
Follow me.
Noise of a cry and thump.
Charlotte, you all right?
Yes. And look what we've got. A laser gun. Doctor, what are you doing?
The L lab. I'd like a look around.
Let me go in first.
Don't be silly, C'Rizz. I can use this to clear the way.
Charlotte, I'll push the door open. Stand back.
I wish you'd call me Charley. Okay. Count of three. One, two, three!
Door bangs open. Weapons fire.
Oh, there's no one here.
The Kromon Lab manager must have gone to replace the Elixir you destroyed.
Door closes.
Present for you, C'Rizz.
No, I
Doctor! Look, our names are still up on the computer screen.

They must have set it up ready to be filed after our pacification. Everything here seems to be controlled by data. The Kromon seem obsessed by records and lists, don't they? In which case, let's key in a little false information. (keyboard) We've all been successfully pacified, yes. And any future data referring to our escape, mayhem, mischief, caused by us will require a password to access. Let's say Tardis. Yes, that's done. The question now is whether their database will accept it.
Input data received and noted. Stored in induction L lab files.
It seems to be official. They'll believe we've been brainwashed, obedient to Kromon orders. How do you feel about that, Charley?
The thought makes me ill.
Doctor?
Yes?
Would that box know where L'Da might be held?
Let's ask it.
Keyboard.
L'Da captured median five. Selected at induction for reproductive reserve. Status confirmed. Companion later found unsuitable for escort duties.
That's me.

Ingested first and second grade Q Elixium. Transformation successful. Hybridisation experiment promising. Advanced to status Q3. Placed in an individual palace chamber on level five. Ingested final expansion Elixir. Consumption successful. End requested information.
What are they doing to her, Doctor?

I'm not sure. Despite what my new data records might show, I don't know what this Elixir is or what it does. Obviously it's very powerful. Worker bees give a female bees special jelly when they need new Queens to form a hive. Maybe this Elixir the Kromon use has similar properties.
That can't involve L'Da. She's not a bee, nor an insect species like the Kromon. She's like me. They can't do anything like that to her.
Can species interbreed, Doctor?

Hardly ever. And certainly not when their physiology is as different as the Kromon and the Eutermesans. I think the Kromon must be alien to this world, but all we've seen of them so far is that they all look relatively alike. No sign of mutation or hybridisation.
So why would they want L'Da?
Maybe they need to renew their gene pool. Their ability to clone and replicate could be weakening.
I have to find L'Da before anything like that happens to her. Where did that machine say she was?
Level five.
How can we reach there? It's where the elite Kromon live. How can I find her there? She'll be guarded by their fiercest soldiers.
What level are we on now?
One.
Then there's only four to go.
Let's get out of here.
I'll check, see if it's Kromon free outside.
Door opens.
Yes. One dark, empty gallery awaits our pleasure.
C'Rizz, how are the five levels linked?
Ramps, stairs, a lift.
We'll stay away from that for now.
Wait. What's that? I can hear something.
It's water. You can hear it everywhere.
No, it's a different sound. Listen.
Yes. It's this way. Yes, it's getting loud. It's a rack mechanism transporting boxes of freight.
Fungus. Lumps of it.
They're travelling slowly enough to hitch a ride. We can climb into the containers. Come on, Charley. Grab the next one. Follow, C'Rizz.
Effort.
Easy.
Yes, good. Now, Charley.
Take my hand.
(effort) Ah, yes. Phew, okay. Thanks. Come on, Doctor. Don't get left behind. You can do it.
It's speeding up still.
Come on, Doctor.
Yes, yes. Made it. That was quite close for me. This is interesting.
Even more so if we happened to know where we were going.
Just enjoy the scenery, Charley.
What scenery?
Light at the end of the tunnel, right ahead.
We've climbed at least one level.
Doctor, I can see the end of the line. There's Kromon waiting. They're armed.
With some of my people as their labourers.
We've still got the laser gun.
You're feeling a bit aggressive today, aren't you, Charley?
Listen, we've been shot at, pushed around, tied up, threatened and well, pushed around a bit more, so yes, I am feeling somewhat fractious.
Well, put the gun away. There are too many of them. C'Rizz, hide it beside the track just before we emerge.
How will we
We'll use our gifts.
That bad, eh?
We mustn't panic, though.
I've got enough panic for everyone.
Remember, we've been pacified. Docile and obedient, yes, C'Rizz?
I'll try.
Charley?
Docile and obedient. Of course, Doctor.
First time for everything.
Clang.
Why, hello.
No station announcements?
Wonder where we are?
Who are you?
You must be the Kromon. Delighted to meet you. Oh, I'm a little stiff. What about you, Doctor?
Let me help you down. There.
Why are you riding the transporter cars?
We seemed to get lost a little. Our Kromon guides were called away. We were given jobs so we thought we'd report for work.
We saw the food transporters so we
Hopped aboard, hitched a ride.
Names?
I'm the Doctor.
Z'Ricc.
Charley.
Access their records.
On that useful little computer. May I see?
You may not. Stand away.
My curiosity. I do apologise.

Doctor, pacified. Assigned for interview, Space Research Director, level four. Charley, pacified. Coded as repros, level five. Also Z'Ricc, pacified. Assigned catering duties, level two. At least one of you has arrived at the correct location. You, Z'Ricc, remain here. The others will be escorted to your correct work stations.
Much obliged.
Thanks.
Take them away.
What do I do?
Help the others unload. After that we must find you a permanent position.
(sotto) Doctor?
(sotto) Docile and obedient, Charley. Docile and obedient.
Beep.
Yes. Come.
Door opens.
An alien for interview.
Ah, you are the Doctor. Yes. Induction said you might be of use to our researches.
He has been pacified successfully.
Then leave us.
Door closes.
You may seat yourself. Water?
Not just now.
I will.
Sucking noises.
Ah! Now, what do you know of interstellar flight, Doctor?
You are a fine specimen of your kind. Strong.
Thank you.
Worthy of genetic scanning. If you are suitable, you could become a Kromon hybrid. Would you like that, Charley?
Oh, I'd (pause) love it.
Sounds of chewing food, lots of voices. Door opens.
This is the preparation chamber. Workers half-digest the food prior to our delivering it to the officers upstairs.
What level is that?
Four and five. Twice a day, lunch and evening feed.
I'm to sit here chewing up their lunch for them, that horrible white fungus stuff?
That is correct.
I've a weak stomach. It should be on my record.
Why wasn't I told about this? Oh, we will have to find you other tasks. Preparation. I will show you the maggot and worm section.

That's an interesting theory, Doctor. A craft that can traverse space. (laughs) Our own craft can convey us beneath the clouds of our world, but so far we have been unable to go higher. But with your craft, we could visit lush, verdant worlds. We could manage their economy, mine and enslave them. Perfect, don't you think?
Yes.
This space craft. Describe it.
Well, blue is a good neutral colour. It would probably be oblong in shape, not too large, with a door.
Blue. Oblong. A door.
Does it remind you of anything?
I don't know.
Do you have anything similar?
Er, can I offer you the water bottle?
No.
Sucking noises.
Ah! Where were we?
Time travel.
Time travel? What is that? Is Time your word for what we call space?
Slip of the tongue. I of course meant space travel. I don't know where the idea of Time came from.
Nor me. It's not a word I recognise. Anyway, Doctor, you might be useful for research purposes. I will accept you for a probationary period only.
My role will be what, exactly?
Speculative consultant to the Kromon Space Programme.
Aren't they beautiful?
Worms, maggots, lots of flies.
Delicious. Mmm. But not for the likes of us.
Oh, the smell!
Decay. Mmm.
Oh, it makes me feel sick.
Z'Ricc, I think you have been wrongly assigned. You seem to have little stomach for our work here.
I'll do anything, but worms? Maggots? Flies? Sorry, but chewing food for someone else's doesn't excite me.
It's a wonderful job, compared to being a contributor to the fertilizer plant.
Oh, isn't there something else I could do?
There's a very specialised job you might just be suitable for.
It doesn't involve maggots, worms, or flies?
Not directly.
I'll take it.
I was impressed with your patrol ship's systems. Compressed hydrogen. Ramjets, of course. To lift a significant payload, that system will have to become hypersonic.
Beep.
Er, come.
Door opens.
Luncheon, sir?
Ah. Doctor, join me. Choose. You, you're a new server, aren't you?
Yes, sir. First day.
What is your name?
Z'Ricc, sir.
Unusual name. Have you always had it?
More or less.
Choose, Doctor. It's all part-digested.
Something just moved in the sauce.
Maggots, sir.
Al dente?
Don't know, sir.
I'm not too hungry.
I am.
Gulps food down and burps. Door opens and closes.
May I place an order for an evening meal?
Yes, that's allowed. This is so good.
Door opens.
Just a moment, Z'Ricc.
Door closes.
C'Rizz, what are you doing?
Best job I could get, delivering this swill to the Kromon Directorate. There's fly pie, in case you're interested.
I don't think I am.
Where is Charlotte?
They took her to Genetic Research, level five.
That's where L'Da was taken. We have to save them both. I've something else under the food trays. This.
Ah, well done, C'Rizz.
I retrieved it from the track side during my rest period. We've got three, maybe four, heavy charge laser bolts left.
Let's get on with your food deliveries.
Door opens and closes. A lift.
I travelled in here before with L'Da. She was frightened, her eyes imploring me to help her.
Now you are.
She's in chamber four. I pray we can save her.
So do I, C'Rizz. So do l.
Level five.
Door opens.
There you are. Late. We should be served first. Didn't anyone tell you that?
No, sir.
High Directorate, then Genetics. I had your predecessor composted for delivering cold food.
Sorry, sir.
This is your last and only warning. Why does it take two of you to deliver the food? This is serious overstaffing.
I just happened to be in the same elevator. Are you Genetics?
Assistant to the Controller.
I want to register a complaint. My assistant has been sent to you without my permission.
Who are you, exactly?
The Doctor, working as the consultant for Intergalactic Grandiosity, appointed by the Director for Space Exploration. I can't carry out my duties without Charley, my assistant.
She belongs to the Genetic Programming Division.
I may be in charge of who makes up future space colonies. Would you be interested in a genetic research position on that programme?
Perhaps I would.
A woman groans.
What's that?

An experiment in one of the Q chambers. You, serve the Directorate their food. You can come with me, Doctor. But understand, if your assistant has already been processed, it may be difficult to reverse the procedure.
Let's hope that won't be necessary.
Impressive. A hatchery for the next generation of Kromon?
Some eggs are experimental. Most won't survive, but enough will to justify further experimentation.
How may I assist you?
The alien Charley. Has she been given the first Elixir?
Not yet. She was to be examined for a Kromonic gene compatibility.
Great idea.
Yes, Controller.
You may have the loan of your assistant, Doctor.
Thank you.
I will always assist the Space Research Department. Their work must be linked to ours if our race is to survive and prosper.
Cracking of membrane.
See, a new generation has just been born. Let us welcome them.
I'm wishing them a happy birthday.
Woman's voice, in pain. Door opens.
L'Da? L'Da.
Door closes.
What have they done? What have they made you into?
C'Rizz! Oh, kill me. Kill me, please!
L'Da. L'Da.
L'Da screams.
All right, all right.
Door opens and closes.
C'Rizz, what are you doing? What's happened?
They've turned L'Da into a huge slug. She's enormous. A breeding machine for the Kromon.
Where are you going, C'Rizz? Stop!
She asked me to set her free. I intend to do just that.
Door opens.
C'Rizz! C'Rizz!
Goodbye, my love.
C'Rizz, stop. Think.
Door closes.
No. This has to be.
Weapons fire. L'Da screams.

DOCTOR: Gallifrey.

DOCTOR: Yes.

CHARLEY: I've often wondered.
KROMON: You informed immigration you have certain skills that could be useful to us, correct?

DOCTOR: Well

CHARLEY: Charlotte.

CHARLEY: What? Hey!
KROMON: You, a native. Why are you covered in filth?
C'RIZZ: Your gunship didn't let us use its washing facilities.
KROMON: You seem rebellious. Note, he is to be ultra-pacified. What uses have you?
C'RIZZ: I can farm, look after land, cattle.
KROMON: Yes, yes, so do most of your kind. Name?
C'RIZZ: Er, Z'Ricc.
KROMON: How barbaric. Put him in the central garden labour force. Interview complete. Take them to L lab.
CHARLEY: Excuse me. Can I apply for an alternative position?
KROMON: No. Repro is for you.
DOCTOR: I need her as my assistant.
KROMON: You can't have her.

KROMON: What if I send you for composting. Processing is complete. Take them to L lab. Pacify them.

DOCTOR: This L lab we're being taken to.
C'RIZZ: That's where we're turned into willing workers.
CHARLEY: Pacification?
C'RIZZ: The liquid they tried to give me. It takes you into the mind of the Kromon. You accept everything they tell you, and believe in their cause absolutely.
CHARLEY: That's something to look forward to. Oh, it's hot, humid. Why is everything so damp? Fountains spouting water everywhere you look.
C'RIZZ: The Kromons seem to constantly need to take in liquid.
DOCTOR: Some insect-like species can only survive in these watery conditions.
CHARLEY: And the smell. It's like living inside a compost heap.
KROMON: 4: Stop speaking. You will wait here.
C'RIZZ: When we are in L Lab, you must let me go first. Be ready.
KROMON: 3: Be quiet.
CHARLEY: Can't we run for it here, get lost in the gloom?
DOCTOR: They've three laserforce weapons.
KROMON: 3: Silence.
CHARLEY: Yes, sir. I'd better get used to saying that.
CHARLEY: Ow! Hey, that hurt my arm!
KROMON: 3: It is the lightest touch beam. The next will be harder.
KROMON: 4: L lab will relieve us of the aliens now.

You will begin to hear voices, see sights you have never witnessed before. Your thoughts will be changed and guided into acceptable modes of behaviour. Let us begin.
C'RIZZ: Let me get it over with first.
KROMON: 3: You will take your turn as ordered.
KROMON L: That doesn't matter. Let him go first. Seat yourself. Lie back.
CHARLEY: It's like watching someone at the dentist.
DOCTOR: Makes you want to run right out the door.
CHARLEY: Yes, it does.

CHARLEY: No, thanks.

C'RIZZ: Yes.

C'RIZZ: I can't. I can't. I'm going to be sick.
